reviewText:
I initially jumped into this game not knowing what to expect other than the beautiful and realistic environments I had seen briefly in various gameplay videos. The overall mood portrayed by the lighting and environment is perfectly suited for the style of gameplay.

With that being said, do not expect this game to simply guide you through the campaign by automatically setting up new missions after arriving at checkpoints. It doesn't work that way. You're expected to figure everything out with little to no guidance whatsoever. To me, this very aspect is the genius of the game. Taking place during a time period devoid of any type of helping-hand technology, I feel that the developers were able to accurately capture that sense of vulnerability and uneasiness that should be expected from a game of this nature.

Overall, for an indie game I'd rate it 4.5/5. It's a perfectly good game that I'll be following for quite a while in hopes of new additions being added over time.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A game about exploring, investigating, uncovering mysteries, with combat more or less as a side activity.

This review basically complements or simply adds to the hundreds of other reviews already posted.

The highlight of the game is the stories you uncover. Each wraith you meet can't remember what has happened or what is keeping them from resting in peace, and will at first only remember one thing that happened. For example one will only remember staring into the barrel of a gun, which will make you assume the wraith was murdered, until you uncover more clues and belongings which will help the wraith remember what happened and you will eventually realise that your assumptions of the events that took place are completely different from what actually happened. Your first impressions will never be correct. In fact, they will be far off. And this is what, to me, makes the game really shine.

There is no true horror in the game. The game will feel creepy for the first hour or so but after that you will realise this is not a horror game.

There is virtually no hand-holding or tutorial. There is a mysterious woman, also with amnesia, who has her own past she is trying to discover who will a few times direct your next move, which include assisting her in figuring out her own. The majority of the side stories also tie together to the main story line involving the said mysterious woman.

The combat is challenging at times but revolves around switching between weapon types for either faster firing or more damage for different enemies, while dodging their attacks.

Virtually no replay value however (unless you want to witness the ending again) as all investigations are recorded in a book so you can always read back at what the stories are, and there are no cinematics.

For $20, you may be wishing there to be more content, otherwise when the game goes on sale it is definitely worth a buy. Lots to do for 100% completionists out there too!

Great game though, really enjoyed it!

reviewText:
Very Atmospheric Game!

As for some of you who don't know, there are not a lot of games that take place in the early 17th century that center around the colonization of the Americas, where this game takes place in.  It's one of those time periods (in my opinion) that don't cater much to certain people primarily, but this game stands out.

The atmosphere is what makes this game, with an open world similar to Skyrim in a smaller scale.  The options of changing color is nice and the whole concept is there.  It gives you a lonely feeling where you only interact with the girl in red and the spirits while enemies are out to hunt you.

The only 2 minor problems I have is the fact that you can only have 3 weapons at a time when there are only 5 in total.  I use the Musket, Pistol, and Longbow primary and not the shortbow and crossbow at all.  I would consider setting the 4 and 5 key as a 4th and 5th weapon slot so that we wouldn't have to set the weapons from the inventory slot.

The other problem is the lack of enemies in the game.  Sure, the nature and huge world are nice, but I feel that some more action would be nice. I find that the Spanish Conquistadors and the Statues are the most fun to take out but there's not enough of them.

Other than that, Great game and will recommend to people looking for a new themed first person shooter/adventure! 9.5/10

reviewText:
At first I was really impressed with this game. The atmosphere, the development of the plot.. etc. But after just a little over 3 hours of gameplay I found that I couldn't finish it. As another reviewer had commented, it was way too isolated and became boring pretty quickly.
When I had first started playing the game, (I played for about thirty minutes and then got busy with school), I was recommending it to all of my friends. After getting some time on my hands and having a chance to continue playing it, I could only do it for another 2 hours or so before I realized I had made a mistake on my recommendation.
It does feel unique in comparison to any other game I've played and that's worth something, and I've played games where you're very isolated before (Myst, Traitor's Gate, pretty much any point-and-click adventure game), but this didn't have enough story to fill in the isolation like point-and-clicks do and so yeah, I couldn't get through it.

reviewText: By far one of the most original concepts in gaming that I have seen in a long time. After watching vids, reading a few short reviews and first impressions"
date: I was sure that I had a full understanding of what this game was like
recommended: what it was trying to achieve
hoursPlayed: and
voteText: most importantly
helpfulPercent:
what type of titles it leaned on to give it its general feel. Very soon into the game I realized that everything I thought I knew about the game was wrong. There is really nothing like it. It doesnt appear to have "leaned" on or borrowed any ideas from other games. Game play is simple and solid. Nothing weird. Nothing that takes a special touch or extra time to master. So many games try to go crazy with making unique gameplay that they screw-up the basics. This doesnt do that at all. They dont need to. The originality is in the way the world unfolds in front of you and not in the form and function of core gameplay. So everything works just fine and anyone can start this game and start playing immediately.

This is one of those small publisher games that everyone should play. Its also a small publisher game that large publishers will likely borrow ideas from.

The color scheme is really pretty genius. I thought I would bring it up to full

reviewText:
Calling this a horror game would be a bit misleading as it is less like Amnesia: The Dark Descent where death looms at every step you take and more akin to Bioshock where you are exploring the aftermath of some possibly terrible event.  If you're expecting a deep and complex story then this game probably isn't for you.  If you play through this game following only the main story then you might be left disappointed, but if you're the type who enjoys walking around a semi-open world and collecting memorabilia then you'll discover more about the events that have occurred and come to appreciate the atmosphere the developers have crafted.

The gunplay is fairly enjoyable and can be quite challenging at times especially when facing multiple enemies with anitquated weapons.  The pistol and musket feel immensely satisfying to fire.  Even the basic bow feels nice to shoot with.   The only complaint I would have about combat is the lack of variety of enemies when in the dark side.  One other complaint would be the bug where stepping into certain rock formations can leave you perpetually stuck in them as you can never jump out, forcing you to save and quit and reload the game.  Thankfully progress is saved.

The game can feel repetitive after a while, but for those looking to do a bit of exploring while shooting enemies with a one shot pistol or crossbow, this game is fun to play.  I hope the developers make another game in the same vein as this one as it shows good potential to become something even greater and more complex.

reviewText: This game is so good, I haven't finished it yet, I'm only to the third fort but I was hooked by the first one. The game has a great combat system and is easy to get the hang of. It's creepy but knows it's own limits and always works well qithin them to provide a stable atmospheric adventure with just thr right ammount of thrills. i love finding corrupted totems and cleansing them in the mini battles that spring up at night. There are always newer and more challenging enemies to fight and the story is very well told. Most of it is discovered through natural adventuring and some learned from the many ghosts that need your help. The only time I get upset playing the game is when I'm hnting the thieves with the silver skulls. I have a hard time getting the drop on them and an even harder time shooting them in the face.\n\nAll in all this is one of the best games I have played in a while and I highly recommend it to everyone.

To solve you must explore the area around various forts to find clues, treasure, lost souls and the like. You must avoid spirts by using a bow or musket or pistol. As well, there is an alternate reality mode that you activate by ringing a bell. This allows you to see and do some things that you can't in ordinary mode. Very atmospheric game. A tip: learn to us the listen key or button as it will help greatly in finding stuff.

reviewText: By far one of the most original concepts in gaming that I have seen in a long time. After watching vids, reading a few short reviews and first impressions"
date: I was sure that I had a full understanding of what this game was like
recommended: what it was trying to achieve

voteText: most importantly
helpfulPercent:
what type of titles it leaned on to give it its general feel. Very soon into the game I realized that everything I thought I knew about the game was wrong. There is really nothing like it. It doesnt appear to have "leaned" on or borrowed any ideas from other games. Game play is simple and solid. Nothing weird. Nothing that takes a special touch or extra time to master. So many games try to go crazy with making unique gameplay that they screw-up the basics. This doesnt do that at all. They dont need to. The originality is in the way the world unfolds in front of you and not in the form and function of core gameplay. So everything works just fine and anyone can start this game and start playing immediately.

This is one of those small publisher games that everyone should play. Its also a small publisher game that large publishers will likely borrow ideas from.

The color scheme is really pretty genius. I thought I would bring it up to full

reviewText:
Starts strong but doesn't really manage to deliver.

In the beginning you will ooh at the environment, get lost in the soundscape and explore the stark and spooky environment collecting clues, piecing together what's going on and getting attacked by evil ...things. It really is quite brilliant. However once you've wandered through the tutorial and first area and you reach the second area you'll pick up the pattern - i.e. how the levels work - and there really is no variety from there on in. You do the same things you did in the first area in a slightly differently landscaped environment. It's not until (I think) the 6th environment that you get the shovel necessary to dig up rocky blobs that have been scattered across all the previous levels (and these are not helpfully marked on your map, nor do you have any way to make any marks on your map yourself) meaning you are left to painstakingly search your way through areas you've already been encouraged to ...painstakingly search your way through... again.

It starts out with a huge amount of promise - a really awesome environment, some great mechanics and the prospect of a pieced together story. However the gameplay really isn't expanded on past the first area and the story, rather sadly, ends very weakly. Your character's presence is never explained - you don't fit into any of the narratives really and the seemingly organic discovery of other characters stories is quickly rendered into a go here
hoursPlayed:
click that" as they are actually surpisingly linear and you simply can't discover the details out of order.

Oh and one of the achievements completed for me in game but not on steam.

It's totally worth a look at
voteText: especially if you can pick it up in a sale or a bundle because the first couple of hours you spend exploring will be truly spooky and quite awesome. Definitely will be keeping my eye on further offerings from this company and I may well return to this just to amble around in such a nicely crafted world."

reviewText:
I loved it 8/10 only because it was kinda short.

This game is a bit of an odd one for sure, I went in expecting to play it for 2 hours and quit. I actually ended up loving it, the lack of any musical presence and the mystery surrounding the whole island was something I enjoyed, if you can, leave the color settings as they are, as it adds to the immersion quite a bit, I would also recommend using a headset, as finding your way is almost entirely reliant on sound.

The game starts out with you waking up on a beach with a crashed ship out in the sea and broken cargo washed up around you, you have no memory of anything, and you start to explore the island, and you see a hooded figure out on a cliff whom sends you a note by shooting it at a totem near you. After this intro, which you have control of the entire time, I was hooked and a little obsessed with finding out who the hooded figure was, and why was there a destroyed ship out ate sea.

The game play is open world, in the first person perspective with a focus on basic shooting mechanics and very light stealth thrown in there. Your weapons consist of bows, crossbows, and muskets as a primary weapons with thrown explosives that explode on contact and hatchets which are thrown directly in front. Your weaponry is obtained either from fallen enemies, hidden chests scattered around the island, dug up from the ground in predetermined digging spots, or purchased via a weapons rack. The health is more classic, with a predetermined amount of health that runs down with every hit taken, it can be replenished by drinking water from barrels, and you do carry around “waterskins” that can heal you when away from a water barrel, these “waterskins” are replenished when you drink from a barrel.

The dialog is entirely text, and often times blunt, still I enjoyed some of the snarky replies I got from one of the characters. The story is kind of scattered at first, with you finding bits and pieces of events everywhere and you trying to connect the dots between all the different characters, but towards the end everything begins to fall into place and you see the wickedness and cruelty of some of the characters, and stupidity and cowardice of others, with some people getting caught in between and becoming victims. Often times you will be confronted with a choice between replies, some of which can have an impact on the story and maybe difficulty of the game.

If you are someone looking for a game with a lot of backstabbing happening in the plot, and want to shoot human and ghost like beings, than this just might be what you are looking for. I strongly recommend it.

reviewText:
At first I was really impressed with this game. The atmosphere, the development of the plot.. etc. But after just a little over 3 hours of gameplay I found that I couldn't finish it. As another reviewer had commented, it was way too isolated and became boring pretty quickly.
When I had first started playing the game, (I played for about thirty minutes and then got busy with school), I was recommending it to all of my friends. After getting some time on my hands and having a chance to continue playing it, I could only do it for another 2 hours or so before I realized I had made a mistake on my recommendation.
It does feel unique in comparison to any other game I've played and that's worth something, and I've played games where you're very isolated before (Myst, Traitor's Gate, pretty much any point-and-click adventure game), but this didn't have enough story to fill in the isolation like point-and-clicks do and so yeah, I couldn't get through it.

reviewText: ADVENTURE!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD

Well, this was certainly an interesting and different jaunt for me. The game puts you in the shoes of a happless explorer, waking up stranded on a beach. And right away, the game disquiets you with the fact that everything around you is in black and white. It is almost as if you're wandering about in somebody's dream, though you find soon enough that the one color you're not blind to is red - it permutates nearly everything you run into, in this story.  You see it in the eyes of strange monsters disguised as Spanish soldiers. You see it on the tattered flags of derelect settlements. You see it splattering the ground with fragments of violent events from a distant past. You are the only person left to piece together the clues of what happened, save for a maiden wearing a red cloak. As far as style goes, this game kept it simple but vibrant. It truly felt like I was wandering lost through the forest trails of ancient New England, trying to figure out what happened to the Roanoke Colony (this game isn't directly about that particular incident in history, but it's not hard to imagine how much the event inspired this creation).

As far as style and visuals go, this game is an easy 9. It was slightly flustering having to take so much time reloading your weapons after each shot, but hey, it's the hazard of being a 1-man platoon in the 17th century. Thankfully as the game progresses you manage to secure higher quality weapons and charms that increase your health or allow you to reload faster. Some enemy encounters can get overwelming, but as long as you can keep a good tempo in combat, things get pretty easy after a while.

As for any criticisms I have, I say them only out of love for this game. But Betrayer does feel like it was a bit rushed in some aspects, particularly with the ending. Not that the ending was terrible, but it was a bit of a hasty punch-out. The free-roam mode after you win provides some context as to what happened, but I would have preferred just closing the case once and for all. If your main character gets the girl and they say their final farewells to Tabitha over her grave hand-in-hand, great. If Allison ultimately regresses and decides to push you into an open grave and betrays you as the title suggests, that's fine too. If the programmers wanted a free roam mode so badly, they should have had a hot tub you can climb into with Allison, Tabitha and that native princess. In short, the ending just felt kind of phoned in, and the free roam mode just felt like padding.

Please don't take that to mean I hated the game, though. I recommend the hell out of it to anyone that wants a different kind of challenge to a 1st-person wilderness-survival-paranormal sim. The weapons test your abilities (and the threshold of your patience) as a marksman in frantic combat situations, and the mysteries of each neighboring fort settlement adds so much intrigue to exploring the countryside. I eagerly look forward to any news of a sequel or new content that might spring up for this game, and I hope more people try this out until then. This is a very unsettling, twisted look at the depths of human cruelty to his own people, and I hope this game becomes more widely known as time goes on.

reviewText: Disturbing story, leaves you thinking... Violent stuff has happened and you must find out who did it (find artefacts and present them to related 'persons', no puzzle other than finding the stuff in the first place), and ultimately you must judge whether or not those people should be set free or left to torment on their deeds. Boils down to a binary choice, yes, but it made me think about stuff I probably wouldn't otherwise.\nGame-play is quite fun, actually, with you exploring several right sized locations for items and 'people' to talk about those items. The maps are populated with some enemies, that re spawn when die, and a nice mechanic is implemented to let you approach those enemies with some stealth. You also have perfect indication if you have been spotted or not, as well as noises that you learn to recognize that point to nearby enemies - which can be pretty hard to spot when not enraged and charging you. New enemies (with accompanying attack mechanics, mostly hit and run but with different flavours) are introduced at a right pace. At least one of them made me jump when they first showed up, which for me is quite hard to achieve in games where the character has some means to defend itself... You must also use a nice mechanic to switch to 'dark mode', which changes the enemies, the colour scheme turns dark, and severely limits your view range. The idea is to explore in light mode, mark up the spots (by hand or by cellphone photos, as the map has no marker functions) and then revisit some places when you have the equipment or on the right mode to progress in story. You also can ask for audio and visual cues to where you should go next, which will help you find the elements relevant to the story.\nOverall the game was a dark and tense experience but also a quite enjoyable exploration. You are not powerless or forced to do stealth, and although you are encouraged and should use it to at least dispatch the stronger enemies first in a surprise attack, charging up in the right zig-zag pattern might left you alive at the end. Still I recommend do not panic and remember an axe to the face is quite effective in discouraging those pesky charging foes.

reviewText: This is a very strange game to recommend. It looks like it should be terrible (clunky gameplay, amateurish presentation, no voice acting, wonky story pacing, 2005-era map inventory, map, and upgrades) but something about it is strangely compelling. After half an hour of playing it, I realised that all these flaws and poor design choices became endearing, and oddly complemented the better elements of the game: the beautifully eerie graphics, the foreboding yet atmospheric sound design, and the apt sense of loneliness and trepidation created throughout. It's an oddly appropriate way to tell the story it is trying to tell, and I actually don't think it would have worked as well had it been more slick and professional.\n\nIt is far from perfect, and I can see how some people would hate it, but it's one of the more memorable gaming experiences I've had in years.

reviewText: Betrayer is a very interesting, if flawed, game. The gameplay is a fascinating take on standard FPS faire. However, at times it can be repetitive. The weapons are for the most part bows and black powder weapons, both are single shot and have a significant reload time. This makes for tense combat but sometimes it gets boring to watch yourself reload over and over while fighting the same enemies. However, I feel that the end of the game makes up for the repetition of the mid-game. Visually, the game is stunning, with a very interesting setting (17th century, new world). At times, I wished that the setting was more connected to actual historical events and places but the trappings on their own are more than enough.\n\nOverall, I'd recommend this game, not at full price though.

reviewText:
Well, the game was good enough that I saw it through to the end and I actually enjoyed a decent chunk of it, but it's just way to hard to recommend such a short game for $22 (CDN). Like, for the same price at time of writing, you can get Skyrim which is infinitely better.

The good is the game looks great, especially if you keep it set to monotone + red, it sounds amazing (the enemy sounds are incredible), the combat works well for the most part, though you'll die fast if you go guns blazing which is a good thing in a surivial game. This all come together to create a great setting and atmosphere that you could really get into.

The bad is that nothing really happens in that atmosphere. For the most part, you're just running across the map trying to dredge up clues relating to a bunch of ghosts of people you've never seen or heard of. Too be honest, with no face, voice, personality, or attachment to the player, it's hard to care about the ghosts... they just feel like quest vending machines. On top of that, basically nothing gets answered about what happened (or why you should care about what's happened). There is an attempt of an explaination near the end but it's so weak and vague that it makes things worse. I just feel there was so much potential for Oh wow!" moments that blow your mind (see Bioshock)

recommended: ok"s which is a real waste.\n\nOverall though

reviewText:
Nothing Special but Not Bad

There are some interesting mechanics to Betrayer, which is good because its repetitive nature means you'll have plenty of time to grasp them as you do area after similar area, killing enemy after similar enemy.  You're explained little at the start, which allows the player to piece together the mechanics so by the time you're late game you should have most of it figured out.

For those who enjoy a slower paced game, focusing on sneaking up on enemies and taking time to aim, this could be for you.  It is not a *bad* game -- but it's not one with high replay value, repetitive levels, and three achievements based on grinding over being actual achievements.  The simplicity of the game would almost be a strength had the pacing been different and more thought put into not making things feel like a game (chests and the typical game-style merchant) would have helped it a lot.  Not a game for people who don't like searching for stuff, even with the stark contrast and cues that help the player.

100% Game Complete in 20 hrs.  I used a map guide, but even without the map I managed to nab all the best weapons as soon as I found the shovel and the longest part was just grinding for stealth kills.

The Good:
- Stylized world
- Interesting use of Sound and Limited Colour
- Discovery
- Fast-Travel option

The Bad:
- Extremely Repetitive
- Lack of variety of enemies
- Flat characters, uninteresting story
- Poor hit detection

reviewText:
I've enjoyed Betrayer so far, having played quite a few hours to get a feel for the atmosphere, mechanics and enemies. I recommend it strongly if spotted on sale, and a warm recommendation at regular price especially if you are a cheap ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like myself.

The game isn't hard to figure out or learn to play, though the introduction scene is short and is not comprehensive. I would have liked to be able to practice more sneaking and using the bow before moving into the game world proper, as this is the majority of the gameplay.

Betrayer relies on text in scraps of notes or with NPCs to transmit the details of the world. If reading a sentence of exposition or a super-short paragraph of dialogue isn't your thing, you've been warned.

I appreciate being able to piece together ghost stories by finding clues with the 'listen' mechanic. Finding treasure chests and other goodies while stumbling through the wilderness adds to the experience.

As I said, sneaking and stealth kills are the majority of the game. How stealthy you are to the enemy is not communicated to the player besides simple simple video game common sense. Crouching and walking are near silent, walking is loud, running is right out. Being in shadows seems to help tremendously, though if you are within line of sight of an enemy looking in your direction you are likely to be found out regardless. Detection distance is irregular. Sometimes I'll be spotted across a flat field with little ground cover, sometimes I can get away with it. This isn't terrible, but it forces the player to be cautious, especially since it is easy to be overwhelmed.

All out combat isn't preferable because the player is fragile. A group of enemies is deadly, and it is best to pick them off with stealthy arrow kills. (You deal more damage when the enemy has not detected you yet according to the tutorial.) When hard combat becomes necessary, it is difficult enough to survive that you learn quickly not to charge into any group of foes.

Progression is measured in areas you move into, as well as what items are available in the shop (which also become available as you move to new maps). The weapons handle distinctly and feel great. Charms add passive bonuses to actions (musket reload speed, run speed, stealth, etc) and most everything you need can be found or purchased. Broken or shoddy versions of weapons can be found on enemies and sold for currency right in the field from the inventory screen. Ammunition is picked up from enemies or purchased from the shop. The game also allows you to conservatively retrieve arrows and other thrown weapons' ammunition from dead enemies. If you miss, sometimes I've been lucky enough to find the arrow in a tree, bush, or in the ground far behind the intended target. Ammo bought at the shop is cheap, but money is better spent on fancier versions of weapons to start, and this encouraged me to pick shots carefully.

The intial black and white visuals are what I heard and saw first about Betrayer. While it was a nice introduction to the game and set the tone appropriately, I eventually turned up the color to saturate the natural environment. This also grew tiresome because the bright red of clues and enemies was easily lost in the woody greens and fields. I opted for a medium saturation, and the game ends up looking washed out enough to know that there was color, but still allowing the red signals to catch the eye and keep the bleak, lonely feeling of the game world. This setting becomes moot in the shadow version of the world, where everything becomes black and white anyway, so I don't feel like it changes too much of the experience.

Sound, particularly listening to the environment, is extremely important in Betrayer. The primary 'listening' mechanic allows you to locate plot clues in the area by briefly adding markers to your compass HUD. The marks change width and brightness when your heading to the item is true, then fade out until you 'listen' again. It's an old idea, but I like the system because it is not as precise as a simple waypoint on your map and allows accidental exploration. Simply listening to ambient noise is incredibly helpful because item caches and enemies will make sounds at a distance as well. This gives the player the opportunity to explore, avoid, or maneuver around these opportunities. I appreciate that different enemies will make different noises. For example, I did not figure out until the umpteenth ambush that Naturals have a birdcall idling sound; I previously thought it was an ambient bird sound from the forest. Again, this is an old idea, but it fits well with the gameplay and setting, and is executed very well.

Mystery, suspense, horror, paranormal activity, and good old-fashioned, New World mysticism are all wrapped into one tight package. Hours of fun were had combing the woods, listening tensely, and hunting Spaniards. I'd give it a solid 9.2/10, an A-, a 4.7 out of 5. Play it, especially if it goes on sale again.

reviewText: Very interesting game indeed. The story isn't exactly detailed as your traverse the beautiful forests but it adds to the mysterious nature of the game. Combat is fun, using bows is always a pleasure for me and sneaking around was simple and effective. Sound was awesome, with eerie tones and listening for whispers was haunting and engaging. Graphics were amazing, lush forests and great color saturation (if you changed the color from black and white to color). Enemies were engaging but overall were not very difficult, although I don't believe they were supposed to be. Overall, I would recommend this to anyone who is willing to play something mysterious with engaging first person combat. It's not very long, coming in around 6 and a half hours or so, more if you spend time looking for ever single chest, scrap of paper, etc. Don't expect a lot out of the ending with this one but it adds to the mystery. Definitely wait for it to go on sale, I paid $4 for it and felt I got my money's worth. I would say $5 and under for this one. Have fun!

reviewText:
If I had to describe this game in one word, I would say it was 'ambitious.' A black and white, open world, horror FPS set in the colonial era from a virgin studio? Most indies would rather churn out another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ puzzle/platformer. But does the execution live up to it's premise? Nope! Does it matter? Maybe.

The stealth system is awful. Many of the later enemies have black and white color palettes, so you don't see them before they see you. Oh, and they can see you instantly from 50 yards away. There's a mechanic involving wind masking your sounds or something, but I never felt that it was worth the risk.

And the game is plauged by a lack of variety. There are only five different weapon types, with varying qualities. There are only six or seven enemies. You can find equipment, but all it does is give you passive bonuses that are hardly even noticeable. Each zone in the game plays out the same way: find everything in the light world, find everything in the dark world, talk to ghosts and move on to the next zone. By the end of the game, you're sprinting from point A to point B just to finish the game. I haven't felt this kind of repetition since Assassin's Creed 1.

Betrayer has a fairly solid engine. There's a myriad of graphics options and HUD options to choose from, which is always welcome from an indie dev. You can even skip the black and white aesthetic and play with color (recommended). That said, I did get stuck a couple times in the geometry, forcing me to kill my character and respawn.

But if you can get past these shortcomings, the game is really interesting. The sound design is stellar. I can't think of any game that has such a robust audio department, much less one that is so integral to the mechanics of the game. When the story comes together it can be superb, but the story elements are all non-linear. Sometimes the story doesn't have the impact it should have because of this, even when dealing with incredibly grim topics like filicide.

If you're a stickler for mechanics, I'd skip this title. 'Rough around the edges' doesn't even begin to describe my experience. However if you're more interested in atmosphere or story and you're not bothered by the broken stealth system, this game will entertain you for a few hours.

reviewText:
Metacritic is waaaaay off on this one.  Unless blackpowder has just made a ton of improvements and optimizations since it was released (or the review sites couldn't figure out how to enable the color instead of playing in black and white the entire time) then I just don't understand the low score.

Betrayer is awesome.  Huge, lush natural environments (some of the best graphics I've ever seen -- especially when the wind blows through all the bushes, grass and trees) with intelligent enemies (love the haunted Indians) that hide behind trees and crouch in bushes and hear your footsteps.  Solid story with depth in the gameplay.  Betrayer is a convincing, surreal world that I enjoyed losing myself in for the 12-14 hours I played it.

In fact, the only complaint I have about the game is that there's only one save slot.  My power was knocked out on my first play-through after I was already 9 hours into the game and my save corrupted on the outage.  Maybe it was for the best, though, as I honed my skills enough the second time through so I was able to progress even more smoothly to the end.

Ok, just one other complaint.  What were you thinking, blackpowder.. the game should default to color instead of black and white.  I don't know why anyone would want to play this beautiful game in black and white.  The color and lighting needs a little tweaking to get the right saturation, but once you do, wow, you have better looking natural environments than Skyrim does--and everything moves.  If you turn the draw distance up all the way then even the grass on that hill 1/4 mile ahead of you will lean when a gust of wind comes along.

Bought it on a 9.99$ sale here, but it's well worth $29.99 or more.  Get it.

reviewText:
If you ever had that feeling that you were playing a scary game and you had that moment of fight or flight even though it's still a game is pretty much my experience of playing this game. First you go get your first weapon then your introduced to some mystery girl then you're not sure like everything else you encounter if you should trust her or not. Personally this game has kept me on my toes. Stealth is somewhat good, but its very useful when sniping, Combat feels great and you can adjust the game to give you even more of a challenge than what you had before or make it easy so you don't overwhelm yourself too much. Second the game visually is a little abstract. If you play it you can keep the black, white, red look to it how its intended or you can make this game colorful and see how bright and beautiful the world is. It's possible the developers did this for people are color blind or don't like how it looks.

As for its way of making you feel like fight or flight every enemy I encountered I made crucial choice whether to go in charging guns blazing or keep it quiet and make yourself blend in the shadows as the enemies try to find where you are as you pick them off one by one in a nice safe corner. The AI for this game are questionable because they're either very intelligent or ignorant. For example, an enemy ran up to me with a knife then quickly pulled out a gun and shot me dead. As I was charging for him as well. As this happened I laughed because it happened so quick, but the next guy I fought he died just like I did. Ammo is not to be taken lightly every arrow, bolt, or bullet is a blessing when you get some.
This game has alot of unexpected jump scares and travelling feels great.

My only complaints or refutes for this game is although it's a great game things like mapping a quest and finding quest items are like finding a needle in a hay stack. It gives you where you are, but does not have a very good way of showing it if you're lost. While Ranged Combat is great, melee combat is a bit weak. There isn't any voice acting for characters so it's like much older rpg games I've played in the past so you'll just have to do what I do and be a voice actor for fun as the game takes you on adventure one quiet not like it. This game is not for the faint of heart and one that constantly needs direction for story progression because there is one you just have to bear the monsters you encounter and scary moments that await you.

If I had to rate this game it gets a 8/10, but I found myself not playing too often, because for me it was probably because I'm afraid to go back on after what I encountered my last playthrough with friends, but I'm not spoiling anything.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game, in many ways, mirrors some of the accomplishments of F.E.A.R. (for obvious reasons); for instance, it forces players to choose and use a small selection of weapons at any one time, and the game has a sense of immediacy in its control scheme lending itself to direct action (I half expected to nail enemies with flying kicks). The otherwordly effect of a child's voice conjured experiences of Alma Wade, as does the duality found within the persona and actions of the antagonists' structures. With these similarities in mind, is Betrayer a good game?

Yes.

Betrayer is a good game, and stands on its own merits: a strong narrative, striking presentation, and effective use of audio. The dependence on audio cues is rewarding. Dialogue between the player character and non-player characters are accomplished through simple trees, whose options are unlocked when clues are discovered. Roaming the world of Betrayer harkened to Silent Hill, but was animated and alive in a way that allow a player to imagine themselves in the midst of a breathing, sighing forest, tinged and tainted with subtle blood-red cues. When action happens, the player's speakers tend to explode with a rushing, beating heart, and enemies are deadly.

The challenging enemies serve to emphasize the theme of the game, and its narrative. There is a lot of text in Betrayer, and it is well-written; the investigations often reveal cruelty or tragedy, and all tie into the eponymous conceit of the game. I'm not sure if spoken dialogue would have improved things, because voice acting on a budget can do more harm than good, and often precludes narratives from achieving the depth text otherwise provides.

While well written and compelling, the text of the game can sometimes be confusing. Players have to backtrack and search areas again, which made the later game feel systematic rather than fluid.

Stick with it and its rewards will yield themselves.

TL;DR:
Solid first person adventure game

recommended: but if you want a run around no brainer you may want to give this a pass."

reviewText:
When i first baught this game I was mostly thinking 'I hope this gives me a few hours of alright alright visuals with maybe some fun combat' but I must say I got much more than what I was hoping for.

This game if far from perfect though that does not mean to say that its not very good, which it is, it just has an unpolished feeling about it. This unpolished feeling though adds as much as it takes away in a strange way with the bow for example feeling clumsy to fire, yet much more realistic, the muskets taking a bloody age to reload is annoying and unhelpful... But RIGHT.

When it comes to how this game looks, I couldn't be happier with it, the black and white style just works well as well as a small amount of colour or very bright colours, It really depends on what you want the game to feel like and the level of detail if really rather good too. And the thing I like most it the games use of red just to make sure you know when you're looking at and for while still keeping the mystery of whet to do with it now that you have it.

Though I feel the main selling point to this game for me is the fact I was able to just get lost in the game. The immersion levels of this game are really something special as it's so rarely done to this standard. Every sound leaves you franticly searching around for someone, even the breeze keeps me in the edge of my seat though that's nothing when it comes to the other world where it's everything I just said times a 100.

The main negatives to this game are just little annoyances that just remind you it's a video game, such as the shop owner just not being there, or the vast drops in pace when you're not sure what to do for 10 - 15 mins.

When it comes to you buying this game I really do recommend giving it a go, though maybe when it's on sale like me as I feel £15 may be a tad on the steep side.

(I realise at the time of writing this I may not have played too many hours and so you may want to think of this as maybe more of a first impressions (Sorry, a very long one at that) Though i plan to play more and look very foward to do so.)

Visuals: 9/10
Gameplay: 8.5/10
Immersion: 10/10
Storyline: 6/10
Detail: 8/10

Overall: 8.5/10

Dialogue between the player character and non-player characters are accomplished through simple trees, whose options are unlocked when clues are discovered. Roaming the world of Betrayer harkened to Silent Hill, but was animated and alive in a way that allow a player to imagine themselves in the midst of a breathing, sighing forest, tinged and tainted with subtle blood-red cues. When action happens, the player's speakers tend to explode with a rushing, beating heart, and enemies are deadly.

The challenging enemies serve to emphasize the theme of the game, and its narrative. There is a lot of text in Betrayer, and it is well-written; the investigations often reveal cruelty or tragedy, and all tie into the eponymous conceit of the game. I'm not sure if spoken dialogue would have improved things, because voice acting on a budget can do more harm than good, and often precludes narratives from achieving the depth text otherwise provides.

While well written and compelling, the text of the game can sometimes be confusing. Players have to backtrack and search areas again, which made the later game feel systematic rather than fluid.

Stick with it and its rewards will yield themselves.

reviewText:
Betrayer is the debut effort of Blackpowder Games, a company of which I've learned consist of former members of Monolith Productions, in other words, guys who worked on FEAR. Naturally, since FEAR is one of my all-time favorite FPS games, I decided to give this game a try while it was in Early Access stages. Unfortunately, it did not stay in Early Access for a large amount of time, and because of apparent time constraints, Blackpowder did not manage to reach further potentials this game could have had.

Pros:

+ Very nice effects. The game's biggest feature in terms of visual splendor is wind. Oftentimes when you are treaded the island, you'll notice that gusts of wind pass by and affect all the foliage around you. At once, this left me in awe. I could've sworn I've seen things like this in other games, but in this one it was done so well. I was surprised at my own bated breath.

+ Fun combat. It's pretty simplistic and straightforward, but combat was a surprising amount of fun regardless. You'll acquire an assortment of olden time weaponry that function well enough, ranging from pistols to muskets to longbows. I found all of them to be quite useful and satisfying. Fighting the spainards was especially fun for some reason. I liked hearing my arrows sometimes bouncing off of them with a humorous metallic clunk.

+ Deep and shaking mysteries! This island has been inhabited by a lot of pretty screwed up people! Throughout the game, you will be solving a plethora of mysteries around different settlements, encountering wraiths and lost souls and helping them figure out who they were and what role they played in the sick situations that had taken place in the past. This is the thing that really kept me going. I've seen a few misspellings here and there, but the writing for the most part is exquisite. It just really makes me wish the game had voiceovers.

Cons:

- Betrayer is quite repetitive. Seriously, as neat as the mysteries are, the gameplay is quite repetitive. There is no real section that stands out, and everything you see from the third level is what you've already played before. I wish there was a little more variety in gameplay, but again I feel this squandered potential was because of time constraints, plain and simple.

- Lack of real immersion and empathy with characters. This is mostly due to the lack of voiceovers. It may be because of tight budgets, but potential for immersion was really lost with the lack of a voice here and there. The dialogue and writing is for the most part excellent, and it makes me sad that Blackpowder didn't make more ambitious pursuits in this aspect.

- Ending segment. I will not spoil the game here, but the ending segment contains an optional task that might as well be mandatory since it makes the final fight easier (and it was already pretty nerve-rackingly difficult). This requires you to scour across all the maps you've been through to the end point, which means lots of annoying loading screens. I have really mixed feelings about the ending segment; on one side, it was really interesting and well-executed, but on the other, the gameplay aspect somewhat fell flat.

Closing: Even if Betrayer stumbles upon a couple pitfalls and doesn't feel as good as it could be, it is still very much a solid, spooky, first-person mystery/action that will find a way to engage you one way or another in its harrowing tales. I hope that Blackpowder will pursue greater projects in the future and continue to deliver us unique experiences not unlike what they've lovingly crafted into this mystery romp.

reviewText:
Short and sweet.

Stealth FPS with an interesting plot and overall atmosphere that is bleak and fresh all at the same time.  It is based on an unusual subject matter (With lots of focus on the difficulties of early settlers in north america from Europe and the atrocities between eachother as well as to and from the native americans)

The most interesting hook is the graphics, this is not normally something I care about in games, but the dev's went to a great effort in making a beautiful colourful game and then encourage you to play it in black and white (sans of course Red tones, which you can always see!)

Just seeing black and white with occasional vivid red is powerful visually, it means flags, people, objects where the rare red's show get your attention easily and feel meaningfull.  Did any of you ever watch Schindlers list? depressing film (as is the game!) but the one thing, above all the horrors you'd remember is the one girl outlined in red clothing.

Yes, even if you are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ sick of FPS games at this point, you'll like this.

reviewText:
Big surprise. In every way. That's even rarer!
The graphic style is quite unique. Monochromatic where only red comes to break this rule. Talking about it, nothing red is so without a good reason. An important point, ennemies, items... Everything red is important. It can be something that will want to kill you but it could aswell be a healing item, that very one you're needing so much.
Whatever it is, you HAVE to go and take a look at it.
Be swift then, stealthy. Cos you're not that strong! If that's an enemy you spotted from far and at the right moment it happens you'd miss that shot, you're never sure you'd have enough time for a second chance.
Talking about shots, don't forget we are actually at the age of the conquests and the conquistadors disovering the USA.
That means the gun you're actually aiming with is everything but NOT automatic!
Miss the shot and you will have to reload it. Powder, the bullet, etc... Will you have the time?
You're no berserker either, 2-3 big hits on the face and here you are back at the camp. And of course everyone had respawn just as you.
Maybe this bow would be better no? Silent style! Love it.
Hope you got a good ear aswell.
For the dialogs? Damn, no. To hear what's happening around you. The cling of that dead spanish's armor, the call of that ghost begging for help.
Ah, yes, I didn't mention it yet. You'll talk to deads. A lot. But we don't see ghosts everyday, right? So you'll have to find a way to slip to the other side. Playing between worlds and so. Funny, really. You'll see.
So, enough!
You got a sharp eye and a fine ear, you got your bow and that ridiculous piece of leather that give you +1 strenght, that's way more than what you'll need to discover what happend here.
Go on, please. You won't regret.

reviewText: This is a game that would certainly not appeal to everyone. It's not like F.E.A.R. (Seeing the developers are ex-Monolith) where you'll find a lot of action. This game is not at all action based in my opinion, but it does succeed in capturing the unnerving feeling of horror like the early F.E.A.R. games did. And this is because of the interesting decision of keeping the whole setting in Black, White and Red, and revolving a plotline that fits well with the game's color scheme! The soundtrack is also one of the key aspects of the game here, since it enhances the atmosphere by a great deal, creating a feel of dread on every corner. The game does get a bit dull after you put a few hours in because it's open world and there are no quest markers. So you'll have to play detective, or just keep roaming here and there to finally come up with something interesting. But I somehow enjoyed this as well. I would certainly recommend a buy if you like horror games, and are tired of all those jump scare" shooters."

reviewText:
7.5/10

Especially for that pricetag, it´s definitely worth a shot.

The game is very neatly done.
Though the story seems dull after some time of playing.

First of all: There are many settings that allow you to adjust the game to your taste.
I suppose the developers intented people to play this game in Black and White (while the colour red is the only colour that is always displayed... in colour - yeah sorry about that) BUT they have added the option to increase the colour saturation in this game.
So people who dislike the black and white gameplay, can switch to coloured gameplay as well. +1 for that, even though I like it in B/W.

Further, I recommend to tick the box where it says that you lose all of your loot when you die and that you have to pick it up before your next death, otherwise it will disappear forever.
Might sound harsh and too difficult, but really isn´t. I died three times so far, and each time I was able to pick my loot back up with ease. It just adds to the games atmosphere.

The enemies are... weird. And deadly.
They usually carry bows, knives, pistols or muskets. (so far - I haven´t completed the whole game yet)
If you see an enemy carrying a musket or knife, kill those guys first. It´s quite easy to dodge arrows of enemy archers.

(If the guy with the knife manages to get close enough and stab you, you´re likely going to die. Because they don´t just stab you, but right after they stabbed you and drained about 45% of your HP, they will very quickly draw their pistol and shoot. And that shot will drain the rest of your HP)

The game offers quite nice stealth/sneaking tactics. You can hide in bushes, as far as I understood, you also need to try to not stay in the wind as it carries the sound of your footsteps. So if you have an enemy in front of you and the wind is in your back, he is more likely to hear you.
That is accompanied by a ton of vegetation that indicates the direction of the wind. So that´s pretty cool as well.

Enemies receive increased damage as long as they didn´t see you. So that is quite helpful for players who prefer stealth, as well.

Arrows can ricochet off of the enemies armor (luckily not all enemies have armor) so be sure to either hit the optics in their helmets (basically try to hit their eyes) or other unprotected body parts.

The arrows have close to no dropoff, so most of the times you can just aim directly at their head.

Last but not least, before I say something story-related:
The developers left an email adress in the main menu where you can directly send feedback to them.
That is pretty cool, in my opinion.


+++ SPOILERS BELOW +++







So at this point I want to point out some things in the story, that I have witnessed so far.
One - the story seems very interesting at first, but becomes dull after your first sidequest and talking to the first main NPC.

So there´s that mysterious woman in a red cape right after you leave the beach. And she disappears again after a few seconds. And then she later appears in an abandoned fort and when you talk to her, she says that she wasn´t that first woman in the red cape you saw, but that it was her sister.

Okay.

Further she tells you that she has no idea which enemies you are talking about, because she can´t see anybody besides you on the whole island.

Okay.

So why can´t I bring her with me and actually SHOW her the enemies I am talking about, because all she ever does is, stay in the stupid fort? It could have an actually logical story related reason, but that´s as far as I am right now.

The sidequest I had so far, was basically a ghost that was missing his wife and son. And you are supposed to find out what happened to them.

And here comes a really cool thing.
In Fort Henry, you will find a bell. Upon activating the bell, you can switch into the other world. The black and white colours invert and the whole game suddenly becomes really scary. (Note I´m scared easily)

The game further adds to the scary atmosphere, because you have to listen" to be able to find quest relevant places in the darkness. And the listening involves hearing ghostly whispers and screams.

-----

There´s more to say about this game
date: but just go ahead and give it a shot. It´s not the best game
recommended: but it definitely isn´t bad. And for that pricetag
hoursPlayed: you don´t lose much

This game doesn't have any side quests but you'll never get lost during the story thanks to the Listen" button you get that shows you pretty much where to go (I should note that you don't get this until the first town in the game so maybe not "never" lost). reviewText:
I initially jumped into this game not knowing what to expect other than the beautiful and realistic environments I had seen briefly in various gameplay videos. The overall mood portrayed by the lighting and environment is perfectly suited for the style of gameplay.

With that being said, do not expect this game to simply guide you through the campaign by automatically setting up new missions after arriving at checkpoints. It doesn't work that way. You're expected to figure everything out with little to no guidance whatsoever. To me, this very aspect is the genius of the game. Taking place during a time period devoid of any type of helping-hand technology, I feel that the developers were able to accurately capture that sense of vulnerability and uneasiness that should be expected from a game of this nature.

Overall, for an indie game I'd rate it 4.5/5. It's a perfectly good game that I'll be following for quite a while in hopes of new additions being added over time.

reviewText:
Try this game on a VR headset...  if you dare!

From the guys who did F.E.A.R.!

The main menu and opening cinematic alone of this game hooked me.  You already know that you're not in Kansas anymore.

pros/cons:

+ very atmospheric.
+ game mechanic is simple, but completely draws you in and overwhelms your senses
+ game doesn't hold your hand, but game mechanics make sense once you figure them out
- repetitive.  Nothing new happens once you reach the two-hr mark.
- map load times felt awfully slow, and broke immersion.
- while you can save your game, there is no option to load a previous save.  So, no mulligans.  (Also means you can't replay specific parts of the game, like the end!?)
- at least for me, by the end of it, you've really lost track of who's who.  Was it convoluted?  Or was I just too busy trying to keep my head from getting ripped off?
- at times you weren't sure if you were just supposed to be killing baddies...  or if you were missing a gameplay mechanic to allow you to progress.

Simply put, this was one creepy game!  I did two hours at night, before I decided to wait for daytime to finish it.
Also, completely immersive.  All in all, I think this game would be too much for me if playing on Valve's upcoming VR headset.

reviewText:
Everyone else already wrote eloquent reviews about this game, so this one is for those that are on the fence about buying and are using reviews. This is a good game. Lots of mystery and exploring to discover the fate of a decimated colony. You can play in black and white or in color, so don't let that scare you. Gets slightly repetitive towards the end, but man, I found this game to be really enjoyable. I wouldn't really call it a horror game. There are a few jump-scares from time to time (especially if you're playing late at night and are intently listening for the distant shimmer of a treasure chest), but nothing too scary. I bought it while it was on sale which I think justifies the purchase. Worth close to $20, but I would wait until it's on sale. Seriously though, this game is a rarely great Indie game and definitely deserves a playthrough. Buy it or become a Betrayer to the gaming community (see what I did there?)


P.S. If you do buy it, when you talk to the red maiden and she asks you if she needs to die, say yes (Literally no one else has and you could be the first to find out what happens)

reviewText:
Open world horror-y FPS with heavy emphasis on exploration. You explore doomed settlements in colonial-era Virginia, fighting demonic Conquistadors and angry indians, and try to find out what happened by talking to the ghosts of the previous inhabitants.

Striking and vibrant art style, glorious sound design, weapons feel good to use, enemies aren't very varied but are quite smart and fun to fight.
The story's VERY interesting (and quite bleak), and told through nice and twisty writing. Genuinely heartbreaking at times.

On the obligatory flipside, the game felt a wee too short, the map's TOO useful (every single item is marked on the map, so exploration quickly gave way to just hopping between markers), the areas felt a little too similar after a while and the kill x enemies" achievements felt like overblown grinding
date: as I fought A LOT and still wasn't even halfway to the required kill count by the end of the game. Not enough to dissuage me from recommending it

reviewText: TL;DR at the bottom\n\nBetrayer is awesome.  It definitely brings something new to the table in a world were every FPS game is the same, Betrayer takes one of my most common complaints of FPS games and smashes it (That being that we always see the same setting WW2, Vietnam, Modern, and most recently the future.)  This takes you to what seems to be the 17th century (more specifically after  the colonization of America.)  where the guns are single shot and the best weapon is a bow and arrow.   This game heavily relies on stealth, most interestingly the wind, you use it in order to hide your foot steps.  Now with all that none sense out of the way let's talk about the most interesting parts of the game.  The mystery and the atmosphere. reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed this game. I have a rule of thumb that when I buy a game, I EXPECT to play an hour of gameplay for each physical dollar that I spent. Is this a short game? Yes. Is it worth the asking price? Definitely. While I have read that a lot of people are on the down side for the fact that the only weapons in the game are: a bow (longbow and short bow), a crossbow, a pistol, and a musket; and the throwing weapons are a bomb and a throwing hatchet, all I can say to those people is, “This a game set in the time when the first settlers were coming to America, did you expect that you would have more weapons than were available?”
That being said, the game was quite immersive. I found myself yearning to figure out what each of the wraiths did to keep them in this world. This aspect of the game never got old or repetitive to me. Each of them had a distinct and different story to tell. Yet all of them were bound to the world by one defining factor that you learn through talking to them all.
The downside of the game for me was the map, honestly. While it was necessary for the game considering that the map for each level, having a map to look at that displayed both the light and dark worlds made the game rather simple to navigate once you figured out how they dispersed enemy movement. You become all too cautious around all of the way markers and can take out the enemies that surround an item. The “savages” (also known as burning men) are a nice change of pace with the fact that the red outline is less distinct for them.
I have also done a full color play through and fully recommend it, especially if you play with the “Death Drop Loop” option enabled. The game takes a new turn in difficulty as the rogue-like aspect of the game comes alive with this option.

reviewText:
This is a mystery horror done well!

Betrayer was designed with combat, and it fits in flawlessly! Combat is a perfect complement to the style, setting, and story! This genre can often be combat free and I personally enjoy those games. However I always find that challenging combat makes the game far more enjoyable! The combat is so fun in Betrayer, that I actively engaged every enemy I found, on the hardest setting.

Betrayer has some really unique art too! That is mostly with the use of colour ... or lack there of. There is a really creative use of mechanics that change what is essentially day and night (that's the spoiler free version). When the player initiates (except in one instance) the art, monsters, and story all change on the same map.

I want to go on, but am afraid of spoiling the ending. The point is that this game is fantastic, truly unique, engaging, rewarding, and positively confusing. If you're looking for a short and complete game with a mystery that keeps you thinking a while after – then this is a good choice.

reviewText:
More like an interactive novel than a game. There is no voice acting so all of the story is told through text, which is fine since the writing is good. The unforunate part is that things get very difficult to keep track of as each character tells you their story (and there are a LOT).

There are enemies and combat in this game, but both have very little depth/focus. The combat system works, but shows its flaws in battles with multiple enemies. The main thing you will be doing in this game is reading, so if that's not something you're into, then avoid it. Also speaking of the enemies, there isn't a whole lot of variety. There are skeletons, floating head things, spaniards, spiders, and little goblin guys that sound like wolves (also more floating head things that look slightly different). They all kind of do the same thing which is sometimes melee you but mostly just sit back and throw projectiles at you. They're also not that scary unless you find skeletons and spiders scary.

There's a bit of exploration involved but most of the world map ends up looking pretty much the same; Grass and trees and some small settlement. Outside of a few houses in the center of each zone, there isn't much to find or see.

The game" boils down to three different quest types which you must repeat again and again to beat the game. Find someone's skull and bring it back to them
date: find a totem and kill enemies to cleanse it
recommended: and find clues to figure out a character's story. These get old very quickly of course. Also that being said
hoursPlayed: there is very little guidance when it comes to these quests and I often found it difficult to tell what to do next.\n\nFor a game that is so focused on story
voteText: the main plot isn't very good or original. It's hard to describe without going into specifics but the gist is that one girl falls in love with someone and her father doesn't approve.\n\nPersonally I enjoyed the stories of all the other characters
helpfulPercent: outside of the main plot
votesHelpful: but ultimately
votesTotal: I would rather have read a novel than play this game.\n\nAlso to very briefly and vaguely discuss the ending. It's awful. It goes from "Okay I know what's going on." To "Wait. What?" in literally one second. It's a horrible shoehorned twist that doesn't fit at all."

reviewText:
NOTE: if black and white is not ur thing, it can be changed in the options in-game

this seemed like a horror survival game, until i played it.  it turns out to be an FPS set in the time era of the discovery of the new world, with good stealth mechanics, a huge investigation focus, and the feeling of a horror game without actually being scary.

+ weapons feel perefect for what they are (muskets feel like muskets, and so on..)
+ using the wind to sneak up on enemies is a unique mechanic
+ the story is interguing, and never stops get more and more interesting with each new revelation
+ the notes u collect r interesting and add atmosphere and intrigue to the world
+ the investigations are interesting to do, and reward you with uncovering more of the story, and do contribute to the ending of the game
+ the atmosphere, this game is ozing with it from everywhere
+ visual style is stiking, and feels fresh (NOTE: if black and white is not ur thing, u can always change that in the options)
+ many areas to explore and cleans

~ weapon variety, while there r plenty of them, the muskets and pistols feel the same with diffrences in states, same goes for long and short bows
~ enemy variety, enemies r varied enough and are fitting of the theme and story

- AI is stupid, it takes away the fear of facing these demonic creatures ( the moment u discover that they will just face u head on, even if u have a musket pointed at them, stealth is completely forgotten and just running around getting spotted and then gunning them down one by one is a much faster option)
- backtracking, there is alot of that to do, even with everything marked on the map
- no voice acting, all dialog is conducted through text, yes u have to read, but thankfully it is not alot, and it only comes in small doses (personaly, i see it as fittign of the atmosphere of the game, and i don't mind some reading in my games cause ur imagination can do better than any other voice acting can do)
- sound effects, while most of them r great, but some of the sounds the enemies make upon death and especially the sound arrows deflecting off of armored spaniards is cartoonish
- diffeculty, the game is abit too easy, i recommend turning on the hardcore mode in the options menu, and turning off the map markers, THEN u will feel the fear
- no boss fights, would have loved to face at least one at the end

all in all, its a solid experience, good story, great atmosphere and setting, and interesting art style.  I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
A game that is brilliant in its scope, quite well executed for an indie, fantastically stylised and laden with atmosphere. Unfortunately the manner in how well it plays out is rather hamstrung due to lack of feedback, repetitive environments and said stylisation hampering orientation.

Betrayer is a first person, semi-open world adventure game based in  the late 1600s in the new world of America. In this you progress through a colony to find out what the heck has gone on, plus trying to figure out who the mysterious maiden in red who follows you about is. The setting helps set the game out from the crowd, mixing small English outposts, strange ghostly Spanish conquistadors, odd natives and numerous ghosts thorough out. It should also be noted that the game is almost entirely supernatural with few people met who are still of the flesh, where most NPCs are ghosts the player goes to sort fetch quests for, unravelling the situations surrounding their deaths.

To further the ghostly, otherworldly nature of the setting the game has a unique aesthetic, where 90% of the environment is in high contrast black and white with items and enemies highlighted in bright reds. While a little uncanny at first, it does give the game a very interesting atmosphere, especially when it comes to the shifting between night and day mechanics. If players want however, the stylising can be switched off, though it does ruin the mood a slight.

With its HUD displaying a compass and locations of note on it, the game is possibly going to be associated with a Bethesda title such as an Elder Scrolls title or one of the modern Fallout games, however in execution the game is split into a number of small areas that reward exploration and small scale investigation more akin to the stalker games. Also, like Stalker, this is not an RPG so to speak. While your character does improve as the game goes on, it is done mostly through improved items as opposed to gaining levels or experience etc... You gain better guns and charms which kill your enemies faster, from longer ranges and you can sneak and move quicker with charms. Due to the era the game is set in you mostly deal with bows,  crossbows and very crude, slow loading guns. While this may sound cumbersome, and I admit it is, it gives shots a degree of weight. Fire a gun for maximum power with the risk of a slow reload and a mass of noise, or let loose with a number of silent arrows from a bow? The choice feels a little more pointiest than an endless supply of assault rifles.

The combat in the game is generally tilted toward the stealthy approach. Enemies can be taken down in single hits (provided the weapon is good enough) when ambushed, and due to the supernatural plot it even justifies that to a degree. While you can go all out and fight the enemies toe-to-toe, the slow loading of the weaponry usually favours killing things off as fast as possible. To help with this the stealth is reasonably fleshed out, using wind and sneaking to cover you, though I'm not sure if light effects this at all. Unfortunately the AI is a little dopey and you can quite easily hide behind a tree while reloading and strafe around so as to cover yourself while reloading. As such the combat can get a little cheesy at times and fights veer from occasionally overwhelming to simple AI exploiting to get around problems.

While the game does very well for an indie title in its initial hour or so of play, it falls flat on its face once the player starts moving on to the later areas. While adventure and intrigue may drive some people, the utterly random nature of where to find things on the maps is frustrating. Mix the game's unique stylised graphics and a very repetitive landscape with few minor landmarks and its a bit of a crapshoot as to whether you find all the ghosts in an area or not. Sure, Stalker's environments were not too handholdy, but here there just are not enough unique landmarks per map to be able to find things. Also, in stalker items or NPCs would be in logical locations. Where you find the ghosts is just a case of combing each map to see if you missed anything. Mixed with the fact the map only updates the locations of fast travel locations and not the unique clues you need to help solve the mysteries means you need to memorise each location for each item. As someone with a poor short term memory, this is an absolute chore to do. Kudos to the designers for making items of note give off a audio que, plus they tend to stand out in red, but it is still messy trying to progress when its not clear where you are supposed to go or what to do.

All in all Betrayer is a laudable game and certainly worth a look if on offer (I got it in an indie bundle, so nice and cheap). However only don't be too worried if you drop the game if you don't have the patience to seek out all the little odd secrets the designers randomly scattered across the game. Just recommended, but not for people with limited time.

reviewText:
Betrayer is an interesting experience. It has a bold look to it, being only black and white with dashes of red seemed (to me) like a gimmick until I played the game. The developers give you the choice of playing it black and white, or with a variety of levels of colour, varying from off-white all the way to realistic. Despite the choice I still played in almost black and white, it was design move that works heavily in favour of the story. Throughout the game you will encounter peoples tormented souls, and you will figure out what happened to make them all ghostly. The stories are usually mundane and it feels almost pointless to do it except for curiosities sake. However, once you approach the end of the game all these peoples stories will come together to affect what will happen. You will have choices to make, and I found it surprising how invested I was in what I was doing.

The gameplay is very crisp, a solid stealth system that does not hold your hand. If you are not behind cover or in the shadows, and you see an enemy, chances are he will see you as well. You have bows and guns, bows have a higher chance of deflecting off armor but are silent, guns hit hard but are noisy and draw huge aggro. There is also melee and some other weapons but you get the idea.

There is no music, but you will want headphones. You're only indication for what you have to do next is to listen. If you press X you will hear some noises, and you will need to know where they are coming from to find them. Also the game sounds beautiful. Exactly like the outdoors. It's got crows and everything.

Gameplay:   7/10
Story:   7/10

reviewText:
Do not think of Betrayer as an Action game. Think of it as a Exploration/Mystery game with action elements. The combat is repetitive but fun, the game mechanics are interesting and entertaining, but it's such a trip to just wander through this game, and talk to these strange beings and hear their stories and explore their world.

If you like games with narrative, games with exploration, games with atmosphere, and also know how to handle an action game, this one is exceptional. If you're looking for an action packed adventure, or on the other end don't like any action, this is not your cup of tea. I, however, think the reviews haven't been very fair. This is an extremely well made game that has a point of view and is well worth your time and money.

Stupid name for a game tho. Then again some of these guys were the ones who brought us the ever so cleverly named F.E.A.R.

At first I was really impressed with this game. The atmosphere, the development of the plot.. etc. But after just a little over 3 hours of gameplay I found that I couldn't finish it. As another reviewer had commented, it was way too isolated and became boring pretty quickly.
When I had first started playing the game, (I played for about thirty minutes and then got busy with school), I was recommending it to all of my friends. After getting some time on my hands and having a chance to continue playing it, I could only do it for another 2 hours or so before I realized I had made a mistake on my recommendation.
It does feel unique in comparison to any other game I've played and that's worth something, and I've played games where you're very isolated before (Myst, Traitor's Gate, pretty much any point-and-click adventure game), but this didn't have enough story to fill in the isolation like point-and-clicks do and so yeah, I couldn't get through it.

reviewText: It is definitely a strange game at first. Red, White, and Black are the only major colors (although you can change that in the settings). Set in the colonial period you utilize muskets, muzzle loaded pistols, crossbows, a knife, and bows to defend yourself from a multitude of enemies. The game throws you in, no explanation outside a shipwreck and tells you to go and find the answers yourself. While easy to get the answers and progress, it is also easy to get lost at times and find yourself wandering through the vast environment and be ambushed by the many enemies that dot the maps including conquistadors of various types, native americans, giant spiders, and spirits.\n\nEverything you learn though, everything you gain is done by your own hand. The biggest hint that one can give without spoiling the game is simply listen. There's no soundtrack, but for good reason as EVERY sound is important. That bear sound might be an conquistador or that robin's quarrel could be a native's ambush site.  Don't take anything for granted and you'll find the game isn't as terrifying as it may have seen mere moments before.

reviewText:
This game is the bees knees!

Gunpowder based guns are a lot closer to the real thing, as reloading takes a long time, making pistols and muskets powerful, one-time use secondary sort of deals.

Also, the game didn't feed me storylines like a baby, which was nice.

In short, this game feels a little like the trailer for The Revenant" minus the horse-back riding.
Haunted colonial simulator/10
