reviewText:
TL:DR - It was fun and very nice to look at. Just make sure to switch the color saturation to normal if your eyes start to hurt from the base color style.

Game isn't very long but will occupy a good 6-8 hours if you take the time to read the dialogue and do the side investigations. The combat is very basic. Look at enemy and either shoot it with an arrow or musket ball or slash at it with your knife. There are stealth mechanics but it's only helpful some of the time. You find charms which act as modifiers for your weapons and melee but for the most part they seem to have been a feature that felt like it was quickly added versus being well though out as you can get some hefty bonuses from them later in the game.

The story is interesting but strewn about the game world so if you don't take the time to dig up every hole and open every chest and talk to every NPC then you will end up leaving this game lost and confused. There is some back tracking but it's not terrible and for the most part if you can get this game on sale or from a bundle then it is worth taking the day to play it.

The game itself has some funny" sound effects and it won't win any awards there but the world itself is beautiful. The areas could have been created a little better by possibly adding some wildlife or more interactable objects but the base game is fine the way it is. You are supposed to feel alone in a hostile world where everything wants to kill you
date: afterall. It does seem a bit odd though to hear birds chirping and crows screeching but to not actually see any flying or wandering around on the forest floor scrapping for food and what not but it isn't exactly going to hurt the game any by not seeing them.\n\nOverall the game was a wonderful experience and maybe with time there will be some DLC or a sequel that will utilize the  base game's features and world to create a successful sequel."

reviewText:
If you are looking for a stealth game, Betrayer is just barely worth it, and only because there are so few stealth games that it gets into the top 10 by default.

If you are looking for an FPS game, a story game, a game with unique art style, a game with intersting morals, or a game that will be fresh, new and unique; you will find some exquisite morsels drowning in a cauldron of time consumption. What was there wasn't enhanced, built up, or polished to a shining beacon, but instead buried and muddied and lost in overgrowth.

It really is a shame, because this game had amazing moments. I looked forward to every conversation I had with the Lady in Red. Though they ultimately weren't substantive, they were still emotionally interesting to me. The setting was extremely unique, and supported and enhanced by all the types of interactions in the game. The enemies were strange and exciting when they were newly introduced. There was a strong atmosphere of forbidding at key moments. Atmosphere was created naturally, not artificially. The weapons felt nice. The graphics were beautiful and it felt good just exploring the area and engaging in skirmishes with the enemies. The stories were realistic in the sense that they were tangled messes of human tragedy, without simple solutions.

But then Betrayer backpeddled hard over all it had going for it.
The progress is entirely composed of digging up items after circling and crisscrossing the map two or three times. The maps have a nice coat of paint, but underneath they are just empty expanses. There are ferns. There are trees. There are some forts. There are large boulders. There are some broken fences. I might not have noticed the lack of substance, I might not have even minded.... except first I had to clear the locations of enemies so I didn't die constantly or have to circle around them for an even longer traversal. Then I had to clear the map of items and clues scattered across the landscape. (this is just arriving at the location, clicking, reading a sentence description, then moving on to the next 40 items.) Then I had to run around the map for a third time, but now in the dark, to retrieve a few more things. Wash, rinse, and repeat for all 8 maps. Don't expect the gameplay to vary or become more interesting (which the game conveys openly reasonably clearly). There are a few new enemies introduced over time, but the interaction with them is largely the same. Worse, what was once strong and salient in the game, becomes tedium and annoyance.

Almost all of the above problems could have been solved if this game was 1/3rd the length. But of course then it would have only been 1/3rd the length. Not a problem in my book, but it would demonstrate more obviously the lack of new content in the game. It is hard to say the game lacks content
date:
because the maps have loads of treasure and things to find scattered across them. Clues are unique, notes are unique, stories are unique, but they don't really add more to the experience. If you have read Atlas Shrugged, you might know what I mean about it being good except that the second 2/3rds are just the first 1/3rd over again.

It is worth it in terms of unique experience and good storytelling plus excellently executed atmosphere early on, but not worth it in terms of time spent jogging across maps and slowly dissolving amounts of fun. 10-15 hours total, ~4-8 hours of worthy content.

It is enjoyable, and yet a slog at the same time. (Maybe get it anyway?)

reviewText:
In the beginning, Betrayer was really interesting. It has a pretty unique art style, a fun combat system, realistic locations and dark stories to discover.

But the game tries to be something it isn't. It's not about shooting enemies, it's about investigating. You find ghosts who don't remember their names and their cause of death, so you have to find out what happened by finding other ghosts, clues and objects.

So, for example you find a flute and a shoe. Each one belongs to a different person. You talk to a ghost and you are able to ask him if he knows the flute - he'll say yes and voilà, you know his name. But you can't even ask him if he knows the show because the game only allows you to ask the right questions. Investigation at its best!

Objects, clues and ghosts are scattered all around the map, so you have two options: You either investigate the whole map on your own (everything is marked on the map) or you just let the game show you where to go next. Which is basically unavoidable unless you want a huge pain in the ♥♥♥ because the ghosts and dialogues are triggered and you never really know whom to speak to next. Also, the ghosts are the only thing not marked on the map.

The stories itself are really dark and fit into the historic background, but once you clear one of the maps you just move forward to the next one and forget everything that's been told before.

It's always the same: You enter a map, explore it until you find the bell to enter the dark world"
date: let the game lead you through an extremely linear detective story and then enter the next map. It's a shame because the combat system is really good and challenging
recommended: but that just isn't enough to keep you excited for about 7 hours. Open world is pointless - the only freedom the game gives you is grinding. Lots of grinding."

reviewText:
I loved this game.
1) Unique, eery ambiance. I can't stress this enough. This game has a immersive and dark atmosphere that is difficult to explain until you explore it.
2) The setting. Colonial Virginia would not be the first place I thought of for a horror/action game, but it works extremely well.
3) Haunting characters. You are confused, they are confused, no one knows what the hell happened, but it was all very bad. I enjoyed the slow reveal of the dark story line in this game.
4) Bows and muskets. Really fun weapons to play with. Muskets are very strong...but if you miss that first shot you might have problems.

Didn't Love:
1) Limited interaction with the Indians. They mostly serve as scenery and have little to say about the current hellish nightmare that has enveloped the land.
2) You might have to resort to google to advance certain aspects of the story.

I highly recommend this game and I hope they make a sequel.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying 2 things, one is I don't think I'm the target audience this game was looking for, and two, I clearly didn't beat the game given my only 2-3 hours of play time.

I got this game because, despite not putting that much importance on graphics, I'm a bit of a sucker for games with interesting visual themes. And on that note I thought the pictures made this game look pretty interesting. Visually it looks pretty spectacular the models and the surroundings are great and give really good atmosphere to the game, so no complaints there.

My problem is I'm not one who's very interested in horror games, occationally having a horror theme to an action game or something is nice but playing a game just because it's horror is rarely a thing for me. And this game just flat out bored me. There were a bunch of circles on the map indicating where things where, so it was like a pc version of connect the dots. Go to circle, maybe fight enemies, go to next circle. There were usually chests of coin, piles of dirt to dig random stuff out of, or just letters talking about some attack, death, disappearance, etc...

The enemies aren't even creepy were just annoying for me, the quests felt tedious and I had almost no motivation to finish finding some persons head, or that girls sister. The shop makes no senes to me since there's nobody manning it so I wonder what force convinces you to leave money there for the items instead of just taking them. Enemies sound like animals and fighting them isn't very thrilling. Water is used to heal you and is found in barrels around the place. My short gameplay consisted of, find corrupted totems in otherworld, kill skeletons around them to purify them, get them all and door opens, go to next map, repeat.

Maybe if you're into this time period or if these kinds of activities interest you the game would be worth it, but I couldn't be bothered to go on after I died once and just uninstalled.

Pros:
Great graphics
Really nice atmosphere

Cons:
Boring quests
Boring fights
In general just boring gameplay

Again I'd like to say I'm clearly not the audience the game was looking for so take this review with a grain of salt. It only cost me like $1 so I figured it'd be worth it just to see what it played like, but it just wasn't for me.

This is one of the most creative uses of third person atmosphere I've ever seen. The enemies are simple and the plot is linear, but there were plenty of moments that gave me goosebumps or made me jump. There is a dream-like quality to this game and I hope that there is a sequel.

Try to imagine yourself as a colonist who sees shadows jumping out of every corner. What was that noise? Why is it so dark? Is that a ghost? Where are the other colonists? Are there indians hiding nearby? For someone who enjoys tales of colonial America, this one is a winner.

reviewText:
Open world horror-y FPS with heavy emphasis on exploration. You explore doomed settlements in colonial-era Virginia, fighting demonic Conquistadors and angry indians, and try to find out what happened by talking to the ghosts of the previous inhabitants.

Striking and vibrant art style, glorious sound design, weapons feel good to use, enemies aren't very varied but are quite smart and fun to fight.
The story's VERY interesting (and quite bleak), and told through nice and twisty writing. Genuinely heartbreaking at times.

On the obligatory flipside, the game felt a wee too short, the map's TOO useful (every single item is marked on the map, so exploration quickly gave way to just hopping between markers), the areas felt a little too similar after a while and the kill x enemies" achievements felt like overblown grinding
date: as I fought A LOT and still wasn't even halfway to the required kill count by the end of the game. Not enough to dissuage me from recommending it

reviewText: TL;DR at the bottom\n\nBetrayer is awesome.  It definitely brings something new to the table in a world were every FPS game is the same, Betrayer takes one of my most common complaints of FPS games and smashes it (That being that we always see the same setting WW2, Vietnam, Modern, and most recently the future.)  This takes you to what seems to be the 17th century (more specifically after  the colonization of America.)  where the guns are single shot and the best weapon is a bow and arrow.   This game heavily relies on stealth, most interestingly the wind, you use it in order to hide your foot steps.  Now with all that none sense out of the way let's talk about the most interesting parts of the game.  The mystery and the atmosphere.   When you first get into this game you have no idea what the hell is gonig on, when you first arrive at Fort Henry and start reading scraps of paper that you start to slowly understand what happens.  it gets really interesting when you start talking to the folks" there. voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I started Betrayer on a whim (and to pick up the trading cards), and three days later....

There's a definite Silent Hill vibe, although a more aggressive kind of creepy. I very much enjoyed the black&white color scheme; to me it seemed to make things easier to see, not more difficult. The mapping was well done, if a little deus ex machina (everything has a marker, which reduced aimless exploration but seemed a bit unlikely) - for gameplay purposes it was definitely a help.

The dialogue is unpolished and lacks characterization (everybody pretty much talks in the same textual monotone), but for the most part that felt acceptable in the context of a ghost story. You don't expect ghosts to be scintillating conversationalists. Enemies were never incredibly difficult, but the archaic weapons added a layer of awkwardness that was fun to work with - running backwards while trying desperately to get your musket reloaded because you ran out of arrows, being pursued by creepy burning ash-men or snarling men in armor with glowing red eyes gave the game its own kind of character.

Pleasantly surprised. Definitely worth playing if you're a horror-stealth fan.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying 2 things, one is I don't think I'm the target audience this game was looking for, and two, I clearly didn't beat the game given my only 2-3 hours of play time.

I got this game because, despite not putting that much importance on graphics, I'm a bit of a sucker for games with interesting visual themes. And on that note I thought the pictures made this game look pretty interesting. Visually it looks pretty spectacular the models and the surroundings are great and give really good atmosphere to the game, so no complaints there.

My problem is I'm not one who's very interested in horror games, occationally having a horror theme to an action game or something is nice but playing a game just because it's horror is rarely a thing for me. And this game just flat out bored me. There were a bunch of circles on the map indicating where things where, so it was like a pc version of connect the dots. Go to circle, maybe fight enemies, go to next circle. There were usually chests of coin, piles of dirt to dig random stuff out of, or just letters talking about some attack, death, disappearance, etc...

The enemies aren't even creepy were just annoying for me, the quests felt tedious and I had almost no motivation to finish finding some persons head, or that girls sister. The shop makes no senes to me since there's nobody manning it so I wonder what force convinces you to leave money there for the items instead of just taking them. Enemies sound like animals and fighting them isn't very thrilling. Water is used to heal you and is found in barrels around the place. My short gameplay consisted of, find corrupted totems in otherworld, kill skeletons around them to purify them, get them all and door opens, go to next map, repeat.

Maybe if you're into this time period or if these kinds of activities interest you the game would be worth it, but I couldn't be bothered to go on after I died once and just uninstalled.

Pros:
Great graphics
Really nice atmosphere

Cons:
Boring quests
Boring fights
In general just boring gameplay

Again I'd like to say I'm clearly not the audience the game was looking for so take this review with a grain of salt. It only cost me like $1 so I figured it'd be worth it just to see what it played like, but it just wasn't for me.

reviewText:
A well thought out, unique FPS with a good art style, great narrative, atmosphere and gameplay elements.
For a 10$ pricetag, this game is a must.

+ Great story and shocking ending
+ Great pacing with both story and item revelation
+ Ranged weapon combat (+projectile drop) are dead on
+ Almost no bugs [Devs were on top of it when it came to bugfixes and support]
+ Crisp controls
+ Surreal visual artstyle

- Inventory / Barter / Item system is pretty minimal but it gets the job done
- The combat isn't too robust and allows the player only one basic melee attack while relying on ranged weapons such as bows, muskets and crossbows. Would have been sweet to have a halbred, broadsword or a pike.

reviewText: This is a good short game and I would recomend it if it is on sale and you are looking for something to do on a weekend or you have a lazy afternoon, but I don't really think it is worth full price. The story is interesting but not perticularly scary and is told through a combination of journal pages and interviews. The combat takes a little getting used to, but honeslty is rather simple once you get the hang of it. The color palett of black and white with the splashes of red is entertaining for a while but can get old really quick. If you don't like searching for large quantities of things or tryings to collect certian items in bulk to complete quests then this game is not for you as that is about 75% of this game. Also as this is at least in part a horror game sound plays a large role so don't think you can play music or try to have a conversation with a friend while playing. All and all, I liked it, but I probably won't be re-playing it any time soon.

reviewText:
Can't wait for the sequel!
Interesting but shallow combat with a story that doesn't live up to the promise of it's setting and premise.

GameplayEnemies usually go down with one or two hits but can kill you without many shots themselves, and you can't dodge or take cover very effectively either. In combat I mostly found myself kiting enemies, sprinting away as I reloaded before spinning around and firing off my one shot.
Stealth is pretty binary, enemies are nearly blind but all instantly know where you are if you miss a shot with your stealthy bow.
More polish and depth is needed to make it more than a novelty.

Story You never find out anything about what's going on or why it's happening until the last second, and even then it's never shown how any of this stuff happened. Nor does it explained why half of it happened in the first place. Why Spanish people turn into angry zombies but British people get turned to ash?

I had to search through the forums to find out how to advance from area to area because how you did so was never brought up or even connected to any of the plot.

reviewText: Very good game, I'm not really a fan of indies, as they tend to be crap. This game is an honorable exception, not only it succeeds in submerging the player in a grim and mysterious, atmosphere, but also the gameplay is entertaining and somewhat challenging relative to modern day FPS. Also noteworthy is the need to use all of your arsenal and weapons in dealing with different kinds of enemies, and the low ammo availability. This game is in all aspects a worthy successor of the old-school survival horror FPS, genere. Definitely worth every single cent.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I wouldn't pay full price for this (it doesn't feel like a $20 game), but on sale it is worth every penny. It's really just a chain of fetch quests, exploration and somewhat mediocre combat, but somehow, some way, it works. The design aesthetic is really cool, what with the lack of color (which you can actually tailor the colors to what you want, but the black, white and red really adds to the game). THe sounds (and lackthereof) really add to the sense of isolation and desolation. And man, this game manages to be pretty creepy. Over all the game does a good job of trying something different, and for the most part it works.\n\nThus far I am enjoying this game. Like I said, it feels a bit too bare-bones for $20, but $10 or less works for it (and right now it is $3.99).

reviewText:
Betrayer has proven to be a game worth picking up.

It's biggest selling point is it's beautiful graphical style, which really set the tone of the game.

It's story started out very strong, told through a series of non-voiced text boxes which really was a positive aspect as it stayed in line with the overall theme of the game and didn't ruin the immersion.  Without ruining the plot, the theme is that you arrive on land after a ship wreck.  You meet a girl, and shortly thereafter you are unraveling the secrets of what happened to the inhabitants of the island.  The story is overall told very well, however one of the big downsides is the last reveal.  It's meant to be vague, but also was thrown together almost as if it were an afterthought.  Despite this, the rest of the game and plot is worth getting through.

In terms of gameplay, one of my biggest gripes was in this department.  Some things were done fantastically, such as using environment to plan attacks, planning type of weapons for different enemies, and the fluidity between melee and ranged weapon use.   There was so much lost potential for what could have increased the immersion.  For example, all of the items can be found by using the map that you already have at the beginning of the game.  Most of the quests" as you progress through the game require no thought - just simply find an item
recommended: choose the only option to make you progress.  It reminded me a lot of Far Cry 3
hoursPlayed: which also for me lost it's appeal due to this idea of "run here

votesFunny: you need to really engage the environment
commentsCount: piece together the clues

column17: and allow it to have an effect on the plot.  Adding this aspect not only will help the player feel more like part of the story
column18: but we can use our brains to take a break from the repetition.  It may also change the fate of certain characters and the overall ending if done right.\n\nWith all that said
column19: I really hope the developers plan a sequel.  This game has a lot of potential
column20: and the next plot can really be fleshed out on the next go with good script writing.  Cheers to Blackpowder for a very successful game."

reviewText:
At first I thought oh my god, what did I buy here. Some black and white game, lots of texts to read. No real introduction, Nothing.
I had absolutely no clue what to do. And the black and white style was nice but after a while very exhausting.
And there were enemies killing me all the time.
So I almost made a big mistake and deleted the game.
But first I decided to check options again.
And now the game was totally different. I could enable colors, which made it a lot easier for my eyes, although black and white was damn stylish. I set the difficulty back one setting so I won't die until I knew how everything worked.
And now it was totally awesome. Made lots of fun exploring these secrets, running around, sneaking at enemies and so on. I can only recommend this game, it's really good. But check options first and bring a bit of patience at the beginning. Then you will have lots of fun with this masterpiece.

Positive:
+ Stylish graphics
+ Awesome engine (unreal engine, running like a charm in 4K)
+ Good difficulty
+ Multi-language
+ Option to show all important spots included (no walkthrough required)
+ Interesting story
+ Great atmosphere
+ Auto-Save and Fast-Travel included.

Negative:
- No introduction what to do or how to play (some sort of tutorial)
- Not much being spoken, so you have to read a lot (someone could read the diary for me)
- Sounds are always the same
- Sometimes frustrating (you have to get creative to get these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s killed)

I'd give the game a 8/10
If the publisher adds some more sound clips (someone read these damn notes and diary pages for me) and adds a little tutorial it might raise up to a 10/10.

@Publisher:
Either get a sound studio to do it or ask the community to do the audio clips for the diary pages etc.
This would give the game so much more. It's always sad if you walk 10 steps, then read a minute, walk a minute, read a minute. Why not let an audio clip play which reads the pages for the player?

tl;dr
Great game, give it a try! 8/10

reviewText:
I highly recommend for players who are into unfolding mysteries and exploration! This game is not only about the battle, but also about going around putting the pieces together.

Great story, good balancing of protagonist/enemies. The protagonist is not too overpowered to the point he is almost invincible. There will be times when you have to run away from battles to survive. I like the fact that you can't win them all. Exploring becomes awesome as it lets you view the scenery and slowly uncover the story.
It is not only a highly visual game, but it also makes you rely on your hearing to survive.

If you usually mix up right and left sides of your headphones, THIS is the game where you gotta get it right!
Good luck!

reviewText:
Simply put, Betrayer is stunningly beautiful and hauntingly mysterious! It's use of black and white, emphasizing the color red, gives it a unique look not seen too often in games and when paired with the frequent breezes, swaying vegetation and nature sounds truly make the experience surreal.

The selection of weapons in pretty impressive for a budget game and there are even charms you can find, that when equipped, will enhance your movement speed, HP and other attributes.  Both the charms and weapons (muskets, rifles, crossbows, short/longbows, etc.; it takes place in colonial times) have varying degrees of strength depending on the type, such as crude, quality and exceptional. There is a light and dark world you must trek through in order to solve the mystery of what's going on in the game and in particular, with the Maiden in Red.  There are collectibles such as chests and letter scraps  and gifts to find and also clues that will allow you to solve other, lesser mysteries involving ghosts you encounter along the way.  There are also a decent number of enemy types, such as skeletons, spider=like crustacean things (yeah, no idea what these things are but they're cool), undead Spaniards, phantoms (skull/deer=headed ghosts....don't ask about the deer heads, freaked me out first time i saw them, thinking it was the Wendigo or something coming after me...) and burning, undead Native American warriors. You can even unlock destinations and quick travel between them, as well as upgrade how many times you can heal. You even have tomahawks and explosives to throw, and like arrows, the tomahawks can be retrieved from fallen enemies which is very nice.

Keep in mind this is a budget game, so the amount of content the developers put into Betrayer for only $20 is truly impressive.  I know this was certainly one gaming experience I won't soon forget. I highly recommend buying this game, even if it's not on sale.  Enjoy!!

reviewText:
One of the few games where I willingly dig up and pocket a tongue, an ear, and an eye.
An intense feeling of dread as you fear you may miss and have to search for your arrow. This is where the horror lies.
This man is so honor-bound that he won't steal anything at all from the merchant's little pile of incredibly useful and necessary hunting materials. Instead he runs around killing ghosts and they drop gold so he can run back to buy things from a man that is nowhere in sight.
In this game, water has been replaced by liquid band-aid.
10/10 Would rob a skeleton again.

reviewText:
this is the type of game that would deserve the neutral/maybe option on steam. it has a lot of good ideas but ultimately doesn't work as a whole.

you're thrown into an atmospheric world that tries to be too mysterious for its own good (which makes the story fall really short of expectations). the mystery is not that interesting to really make you put up with the gameplay, which you soon realise consists of fetch quests and tons of filler - very simplistic, gets stale quickly.

the gameplay mechanics are not balanced, with stealth being pretty much useless and an artificial way to lenghten the game. the combat doesn't feel precise, which ain't helped by the atrocious pathfinding of your enemies.

visually striking - the colour and contrast customisation freshen up the experience.
the audio design is top notch - the best thing about Betrayer. skeletons are finally spooky again and I've never been so careful around statues.


looked to be a short game worth finishing at first. six hours later I'm confident I will not return to it. collectathons are not my cup of tea.

Let's just be glad Monolith have been ressurected.

reviewText:
Not gonna lie, not recommending this game proved to be a hard decision.  I really wanted to like it, and even fooled myself to for a time, a somewhat refreshing look at a stealth-horror-investigation-shooter?  Here are the reasons that made this game was hard to downvote.
-Amazing environment
-Unique Story
-Solid Gameplay
-Very Fair Price
Now with a list like that, how could I damn such a game?  Well the combat did prove enjoyable though the enemy variety proved to be fairly bland, not the types or number, just how they had the same behavior and mode of attack.  That along with the give and take story that really demanded finishing.  Once you spend an hour or two in the game, you realize it is rather shallow and becomes a grinding Easter egg hunt, wrought with cheap scares to keep you on your toes until you are upgraded enough that you no longer care to be tactical or stealthy.  Then it’s fast traveling back and forth, as well as revisiting areas you’ve scoured already.  The dialogue proved dreadful as well as many systems that appear mostly hollow, like gifting your red friend things you’ve dug up like an obedient puppy and not much to show for regardless of if she accepts it or not.  The game isn’t spotless either as I have also found myself on more than one occasion being lodged into rocks and walls maneuvering with a borderline useless jump key.  Speaking of environments, I hope you like forests, because that is all you are going to get in this game.  So if you are into a cheap romp through the woods with a passible story where you collect junk kill skeletons and talk to ghosts for 5 hours, feel free go on ahead.  I just can’t, although I can safely say I gave the game the benefit of finishing it at least.

reviewText:
A compelling tale of discovery, ghosts, regret and, naturally, betrayal.

You travel around a section of woodland near the coast of the New World with no real understanding of who you are or what you must do, meeting variuos trapped spirits along the way. Each wraith you encounter has its own unique baskstory, which normally ties into the stories of the other wraiths in the area. There is areally chilling overarching plotline which retains a couple of eerily ambiguous elements and it only picks up speed as you go through the game.

This is a superb short game (you could grind it out in a week easily, and I fully suggest you do so) but not without content. True, there could be a bit more variation in the maps/objectives, but that's really not what this game is about; rather it is something to play slowly and contemplatively, exploring every tree stump and rock face and traversing every inch of the woodland on the hunt for clues. It somehow avoids being boring despite being really much of the same for the duration.

The graphics are great and run wonderfully, the sound design is EXCELLENT and is one of the few games I can think of where sound was actually an aspect which jumped out at me, and the gameplay is simplistic and smooth. Loot and weapons are fairly standard, but you do find some interesting variations on the same weapons as you get later in the game. There are multiple incarnations of each weapon type, getting progressively stronger as the game progresses.

At the start of the game you feel so weak, only being able to take on a couple of enemies at once at a push, stealth really is the preference for early game. Towards the end, however, it is possible to find weapons capable of taking down a skeleton in one hit, even the floating skulls are no match for you near the end, but combat is not the focus of the game and you never feel overpowered.

My favourite aspect of Betrayer is the level of customisation the game gives you. you can choose to play the game in black and white or colour, with variable saturation, as well as having control over the enemy difficulty at any point in the game. The best part of customisation, however, is the map, which you can set to display the locations of various goals, or, as I prefer, not. It is useful to be able to turn these settings on after the plot draws to a close for completionists out there, just so you can polish off the few chests you might have missed.

One downside is that it also seems to highlight chests/objectives you have previously attained in the map, although this only happens once you return to an area you have previously visited. I also noticed that, at one point in the game, it decided to invert the stereo; so what should have been in my right ear was suddenly in my left visa vera, which was incredibly disorientating in game which utilises sound to direct you to the wraiths. However the fix was easy, as I just swapped my headphones round.

Apart from these two very minor greivances, Betrayer is a great game from such a small developer and at a great price. I fully recommend it to anyone looking for an atmospheric daytime-horror game. Theres something in this game which is certainly creepier and more harrowing than any xenomorph jumping through the air vents. Its more subtle than that. Buy this game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I started Betrayer on a whim (and to pick up the trading cards), and three days later....

There's a definite Silent Hill vibe, although a more aggressive kind of creepy. I very much enjoyed the black&white color scheme; to me it seemed to make things easier to see, not more difficult. The mapping was well done, if a little deus ex machina (everything has a marker, which reduced aimless exploration but seemed a bit unlikely) - for gameplay purposes it was definitely a help.

The dialogue is unpolished and lacks characterization (everybody pretty much talks in the same textual monotone), but for the most part that felt acceptable in the context of a ghost story. You don't expect ghosts to be scintillating conversationalists. Enemies were never incredibly difficult, but the archaic weapons added a layer of awkwardness that was fun to work with - running backwards while trying desperately to get your musket reloaded because you ran out of arrows, being pursued by creepy burning ash-men or snarling men in armor with glowing red eyes gave the game its own kind of character.

Pleasantly surprised. Definitely worth playing if you're a horror-stealth fan.

reviewText: A giant mixed bag.  The game itself is pretty decent: exploring the settlements and investigating the deaths of their former residents is decently entertaining, the combat isn't terribly deep, but still handled well, the visuals are all excellent and effective.  Unfortunately, though, the overall narrative (especially the ending) is flat to lackluster.  While the backstories of the ghosts are quite tragic and thought out well enough, having them told to us flatly by unemotive, similar looking ghosts via text simply isn't that exciting and worse yet, gets repetitive.  Only making matter worse, the end is unsatisfying, raises questions that almost no one is bound to care about, and ultimately leaves us with zero answers regarding our character's identity.  Seriously, who are we playing?  As far as I can tell it's a generic nice guy wandering through the forest armed to the teeth, talking to spirits, and suffering from schizophrenia so severe he thinks all spaniards are beastly monsters and all native americans are on fire.\n\nIt's ultimately not a bad game, and if you're really interested, give it a shot.  That said, I really can't recommend this game to the average person.

reviewText: I was going to write a list of Pros and Cons
date: but then I realized that although the pros were things done well, the cons were things the game didn't even try to do, because it wasn't about those things.  So, I re-wrote the list as Things This Game Is and Is Not About."  "Bottom Line" at the top
recommended:
for TL;DR purposes.

Bottom Line:
This is not a triple-A title
hoursPlayed: and it isn't trying to be.  It's trying to go in a different direction and do things that triple-A titles *don't* do
voteText: and specifically avoid doing the things they already do better.  If you like the "Things This Game Is About
helpfulPercent: and are not bothered by a total lack of Things This Game Is Not About
votesHelpful: then you will like this game, because it is VERY good at what it *is* about.  However, if you find the game too slow
votesTotal: boring
votesFunny: lacking weapon diversity
commentsCount: or not challenging enough
column16:
then this game is a poor match for you, because it is not about scratching those types of itches.

Things This Game Is About:
~ Spooky atmosphere.  Not frightening, shocking, or horrifying - just slightly spooky.  Something is... *off*.
~ Exploration.  There are numerous ways to pick your way through the game, but turning on all the map markers and following the optimal path will be tremendously boring.  Instead, exercise a bit of self-control and wait to turn on those markers until you've found most of the stuff but aren't sure where those last two or three things are.
~ Isolation.  This is a doomed colony, and you're there to sort out the wreckage, not interact with a cast of dozens of vibrant and interesting NPCs.
~ Paying attention to what you hear (and how audible you are) more than what you see.  The devs wanted to create a game where aural cues are more important than visual ones, and while there are still visual cues for the hearing-impaired, the aural cues are far more important and reliable.
~ Helping ghosts make peace with their deaths, which they can't remember, by figuring it out for them.  You may well piece together a story before the ghost does, but they might need some object or other trigger to be able to move on.  Just accept that this is how ghosts work - it's about their peace, not your understanding.
~ Patiently planning your attacks.  More like Tenchu (the first one), where you can get in over your head if you fail to spot something, than like Shadow of Mordor, where you're *supposed* to overcome superior odds and adapt your plans on the fly.  Actually, it's even farther in the Tenchu direction than Tenchu is.

Things This Game Is Not About:
~ Broad weapon choices (would be period-inappropriate).
~ Slaughtering your enemies in droves (would detract from the atmosphere).
~ Fast-paced gameplay (would detract from the atmosphere).
~ Being super-exciting, epic, or over-the-top in any way (would detract from... look, this is a very understated game).
~ Magic spells, talent trees, mega bosses, epic weapons, phat lewtz, or pretty much anything that most triple-A titles go over-the-top on to try to stand out from their competitors.
~ Puzzles.  The investigations" you undertake
column17: such as they are
column18: are not intellectually demanding.  There are no puzzles in this game
column19: no intuitive leaps to make; if you can just find the MacGuffins the ghosts are looking for
column20: they'll fill in part of the colony's story for you and be able to move on themselves.  This is not a framework for a puzzle
column21: it's a justification of the fetch-quest mechanic (the ghosts are stuck
column22: therefore they can't go on their own errands)."

reviewText:
Good for an indie title. But the game could benefit greatly from voiced dialogue. The premise has a lot of potentional that could be realized by a bigger budget.  However, as it exists it is not very engaging. The monsters aren't particularly frightening; the astmosphere isn't particularly chilling. For example, you are an 17th century English explorer and discover that the King's colony is a ghost town. Then you encounter a spirit. Then you enter an Otherworld, which seems to be similar to Silent Hill's Otherworld. There's a Maiden in Red who has amnesia. After seeing all this, you plod along as if it's Sunday at Nottingham. Meh.

Edit: Having just looked up the plot, it does seem like an interesting story. But the lesson is no matter how interesting it is you must get there first. I'm not going to spoil the plot, but basically it is FEAR with muskets and bows, and instead of a fictional government agency you are an English explorer.

As to what is scary, FEAR was scary when it came out. Most recently there is Layers of Fear. The latter doesn't involve any firearms and is basically a walking simulator, but when it comes to that crawling sensation, it's top-notch. Though there were definitely a few sequences in that game where I wished I had a knife or something. Sending a man unarmed into a haunted mansion is not cool.

reviewText: Betrayer is phenomenally successful in creating an atmosphere of vulnerability and unease, and it's an aesthetic marvel, but its core gameplay loop and overall structure left me cold.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
The game's not very engaging from what I've played:

The black and white aesthetic with the occasional red object is neat at first, but it quickly gets monotone and tiring.

There's very little in the way of sound design, and what is there sets up the mood well, but it's a case that quality just doesn't supersede quantity.

Some experimentation is needed to figure out what all the buttons do on the pad. Figuring out how to switch weapons was especially polarizing, seeing as how you don't get a radial menu or anything, but instead a single button (LB) cycles through all three weapons at once. Otherwise the controls are fine.

The interface feels very clunky in some spots. Cycling through fast-travel locations is a major pain, and so is navigating your equipment menu. The minimalistic interface design also has the unintended side-effect of making the whole thing seem very budget-y and not very well implemented.

The combat is a bit one-sided. At first it feels quite visceral, with enemies dashing towards you as you try to put one more arrow into them, and the game does have a neat mechanic in masking the noise you make when a gust of wind hits your surroundings. However, the combat just doesn't feel deep enough: you get a handful of ranged weapons which all perform very similarly to one another, a short-range tomahawk which you can throw for massive damage, and a few bombs which help to thin out crowds. Enemy patterns don't differ so much from one another that you need to adopt any different strategies: aggro enemies in front of you, wiggle left and right repeatedly to dogde projectiles, fire projectile of your choice back at them. The odd inclusion of an option to drop your equipment when you die is meant to make combat more tense, but it doesn't add anything meaningful to it in my opinion, it just makes it more annoying.

I couldn't figure out how to attach myself to the story in any point. You're a shipwreck making his way inland where Englishmen and Spaniards have set up camp and constantly have skirmishes with indians and each other. Death permeates all of the camps however, and after digging around a bit, you gain the ability to talk to the wraiths of the people that lived in the region, and piece together how they died. Reading by this narrative ultimately isn't really interesting: while the backstory of these people is well-written and often pretty gruesome, the medium by which they are delivered falls short: there are no cutscenes and no voice acting, leaving you with a pretty paltry dialogue box and your imagination (nothing wrong with that, it's just not for me).

There's also a lady that follows you around in the camps, the only other apparent living human you can talk to. You can give her things and talk about the apparitions you're seeing, but she doesn't share in your ability to see the dead or the strange ashen figures scattered throughout the camp. Making you question the main character's sanity like that is a legitimately cool plot point, but the lady herself is hardly engaging: like the other characters, she lacks a voice actor, and any other kind of different idle animations or behavior. Her dialogue isn't even that engaging to make you care for her all that much, and giving her gifts, if it did anything at all after, passed right by my head.

There's just not that much great to say about the game. I gave it a few hours, and made it to the third map you can get to. Maybe that's not enough time, but the lack of sound assets, strange choice of visual style, clunky interface and simplistic (unnecessary even?) combat meant that I didn't want to give it any more of a chance for it to grab me. It asks for a fair price though, so maybe someone with a bit more patience can find enjoyment in it.
